text: All pixels will have 2-3 samples per exposure downloaded (3-4 if there is an additional ground station, these will be the 10th (TBV) and 20th (TBV) read of each exposure.

Every pixel where the up-the-ramp (UTR) sampling fails by 3-sigma will have every read downloaded (including those due to saturated pixels, cosmic ray hits, and all other sources of UTR failure; we estimate this to be roughly 2% of all images).
Every read from every pixel of every exposure will be downloaded for 1% (TBV) of all exposures of all fields.   (Alternatively, 1% of the pixels of each exposure will have every read downloaded.)
The data will be downloaded from the spacecraft to GSN at most every 12 hours.
Data from GSN will sent to the SSOC within <2 hours 80% of the time during second half of the spring and first half of the fall microlensing seasons.
Observations of all fields will be taken in all filters at least once per week.

Stepped observations of a crowded field (but less crowded than the microlensing fields) with offsets that would sample the scale of the astrometric detector artifacts.  These fields should have stars with good Gaia parallaxes to set the absolute scales.
Uncalibrated data and light curves will be provided for alerts on time scale of <20 hours, preferably <14 hours.
The ISOC shall produce alerts and make them available to the community within 2 hours of the data arriving at the SSOC.
Calibrated moment curves will be provided on a daily time scale.
Derived calibration products will be provided on a weekly time scale.
Supersampled stacked images will be provided every season.
Results of injection and recovery tests will be provided every season.

The final data products will include the calibrated moment curves, relative proper motions and parallaxes, flagged astrometric binaries, and detection efficiencies for microlensing events for each light curve and planet sensitivities for every microlensing event.
